awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Bridge to Physics and Astronomy Doctorates for Students with Financial Need
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, this project  at California State Polytechnic University Pomona (CalPoly Pomona) will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need. This project will fund 146 scholarships over five years for students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in physics and astronomy. Participating scholars will join a cohort-based mentoring and undergraduate research program spanning a diverse network of more than 50 California higher education institutions.  These institutions are dedicated to the goal of increasing the number of students pursuing PhDs in physics, astronomy, and associated STEM disciplines. Led by CalPoly Pomona and the University of California Irvine in Southern California, and by San Jose State University and the University of California Santa Cruz in Northern California, more than 140 physics and astronomy faculty at the 24 California State University (CSU) and University of California (UC) campuses in the bridge network will serve as mentors to scholars supported by the project. In addition to receiving biweekly mentoring and progress monitoring by pairs of one UC and one CSU professor, these scholars will also receive full need-based scholarships during their junior and senior years, monthly professional development workshops, and supervised research opportunities via the successful NSF-funded CAMPARE program.

Given the size and diversity of the California secondary education system, the success of this S-STEM Track 3 project will likely significantly increase the number of PhDs nationwide earned by underrepresented minorities in the fields of physics and astronomy. All low-income students enrolled in a participating CSU campus are eligible for this California Bridge (Cal-Bridge) program, which searches for students with unusual potential, using holistic review and research-based criteria developed by successful bridge programs such as the Fisk-Vanderbilt Master's-to-PhD Bridge program. Unlike other existing bridge programs, Cal-Bridge begins with students during their formative undergraduate years, focusing on preparation rather than remediation. This multifaceted support will mitigate known barriers to graduate school entry for high-achieving, motivated students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds, and will thus greatly increase the probability they complete their undergraduate degree and gain entry to PhD programs. The project also involves multi-method social science research to understand the networks of scholars and institutions formed because of partnerships between Minority/Hispanic Serving Institutions and Research Universities, and the effect of those networks on recruitment and admissions to participating UC physics and astronomy departments. Over the five-years, social network analysis and qualitative case study methods will be used to capture patterns in Cal-Bridge Scholars' graduate school admissions and enrollment, as well as in impediments to these outcomes. These results, along with the project's growing connections with institutions beyond California, will have the potential to influence the national landscape of equitable participation by low-income students in STEM higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award supported research activities associated with the Cal-Bridge project (https://calbridge.org/). The mission of Cal-Bridge is to “create opportunities for historically underrepresented groups, including women, underrepresented minorities (URMs), first generation students, members of the LGBTQ+ community, and those with disabilities, to participate and advance in STEM fields in order to increase diversity in STEM PhD programs and the STEM professoriate in California and nationwide.”  A research team at the University of Southern California executed three phases of research to answer three questions:

1.        What networks of graduate program application, admission, and enrollment emerge in the statewide Cal-Bridge program?

2.        How do partnerships between MSI/HSI’s and research universities expand individual and institutional trust networks affecting graduate school admissions? What impedes these networks’ development?

3.        How do such partnerships contribute to diversity efforts in participating departments?

Question 1: To answer the first question, we used a technique called social network analysis to look at patterns in the universities Cal-Bridge scholars from 2015-2022 applied to, were admitted to, and ultimately enrolled in. Although they applied throughout the University of California system, one program – the physics and astronomy PhD program at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) – emerged very clearly as the place Cal-Bridge scholars most often were admitted and enrolled. 

Question 2: To answer the second question, and to help the broader Cal-Bridge and STEM communities understand what they might also do to help enroll more socioeconomically, gender, and racially/ethnically diverse students, we conducted an in-depth case study of the physics and astronomy PhD program at the University of California, Irvine that allowed us to tell their story. We interviewed current students, alumni, faculty, and staff to understand how the program had come to be a “hot spot” for Cal-Bridge and other students from historically underrepresented backgrounds.

We found that Cal-Bridge at UCI supported the development of trust on the part of both faculty and prospective students. Professors learned to extend trust to students from backgrounds that they might not have previously. Changes in how the program operated, such as what they looked for in the admissions process and how interacted with students, were aligned with similar change efforts at the university and in the field of astronomy. Cal-Bridge also facilitated research experiences that trained students in skills expected of them in graduate school; this made faculty feel like it was safe to admit students from less prestigious colleges and universities.

From the student perspective, Cal-Bridge helped students develop trust in UCI as a place to apply and, eventually, enroll. Mentors and past Cal-Bridge scholars told our research team that UCI broadened scholars’ horizons about where to apply and provided crucial information about the quality of the environment that positively affected their interest in enrolling. Based on our findings, we developed a model that describes influences on trust in the transition to graduate school.

Question 3: The research team then shifted gears to study how admissions committees in PhD programs with connections with Cal-Bridge select students. We wanted to understand how they balance a variety of considerations, in particular what they do to encourage diversity while still complying with state laws that ban racial preferences. Using qualitative research methods, we studied the admissions process in two departments over two admissions cycles each. We found that both programs, one which we call Western and the other Eastern, took seriously academic qualifications as a foundation. However, more academically qualified students applied than they had room for. At this point both programs looked at additional qualities that would make the student and program stronger.

At Western, the admissions committee used their review process to rethink typical ideas about excellence and they included a new dimension of excellence— “community contributions”—in their evaluations of applications and interviews with finalists. Their admissions committee included current graduate students and the two co-chairs made an effort to ensure that their voices were heard and their votes counted.

At Eastern, we found a strong role for technology in the admissions process. They, too, considered professional qualities above and beyond academic qualifications. Specifically, they looked at applicants’ experiences overcoming adversities as a sign of resilience, and they included a race-neutral “diversity impact” line on their evaluation rubric. Connecting these, some committee members described using “diversity impact” to reward applicants that had overcome adversity.

Dissemination and Significance: Our goal was to understand the changing landscape of application, admission, and enrollment in physics and astronomy graduate programs. Given changing laws around the consideration of race, many universities are seeking legally compliant ways to make real their commitments to diversity. Cal-Bridge and our research highlights ways that they can do so. We have shared this work with STEM and education research audiences, as well as higher education administrators by translating findings into a workshop on systemic change.
